advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1976)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the pictured floppy drives have never been released.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new Laser 3000" <br><br> "At last, un complete PRO system with disk drive for 4980 F"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SUPERBRAIN II ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>SuperBrain II's internal circuitry has been completely redesigned. There were four models availables, from 350 KB to 10 MB of storage capacity.<br><br> The new version offered a faster enhanced disk operating system, new video visual attributes ans better graphics capabilities. <br><br> Prices started at $2,495</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>Really nice advert, we love it.<p class="petitgris">Byte Magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN THE KITCHEN...</strong></font><br><blockquote>A TO-7 in the kitchen? For sure it makes smile the woman!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1976 PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the 16K static RAM expansion is more expensive than the computer itself.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The ZX-81 will soon become a precious work tool"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JULY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil has all talents"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br> Special Spectrum offers before christmas period. Packages including a Sinclair joystick and 6 games.<br><br> Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The new Sinclair ZX Spectrum+3 is a real hero because it helps you to be one.<br> The fantastic 128K memory gives you the power to outsmart the most sophisticated ennemy...<br> ...But the real hero is the person who buy it...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> Z-2D ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Z-2D 1977 price list:<br><br> - Kit version with 1 F.D. drive: <b>$1495</b><br> - Assembled version: <b>$2095</b><br> - Additional F.D. drive: <b>$495</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.description: The SDK-86 (System Design Kit) was the first available computer using the Intel 8086 microprocessor. It was sold as a single board kit at a cheaper price than a single 8086 chip! because Intel thought that the success of a microprocessor depends on its evaluation by as many users as possible. All major components were socketed and the kit could be assembled by anyone having a limited technical knowledge thanks to a clear and complete assembly manual. The system could be used with the on-board keyboard and display or connected to a serial video terminal. The internal ROM monitor offered the following commands: S (Substitute Memory): Displays / Modifies memory locations X (Examine / Modify registers) : Displays / Modifies 8086 registers D (Display memory): Displays memory content M (Move): Moves block of memory data I (Port Input): Receives data from input port O (Port Output): Send data to input port G (Go): Execute user program N (Single Step): Execute single program instruction R (Read File): Read object file from tape to memory W (Write File): Writes block of memory to tape.
computer.name: SDK-86
computer.ports: Processor bus, Parallel and Serial I/O

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>SDK_86 documentation included<br><br> - Assembly manual<br> - User's manual and user's guide<br> - 8086 reference guide<br> - Monitor listing<br> - System schematics. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DOCUMENTATION DETAIL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Detail of a construction step in the assembly documentation</blockquote>
